thread.title: Wyoming wide receiver Jake Maulhardt off to career year
thread.title_full: Wyoming wide receiver Jake Maulhardt off to career year

title: Wyoming wide receiver Jake Maulhardt off to career year
text:
Wyoming wide receiver Jake Maulhardt has career high 30 receptions, 312 yards and 3 touchdowns 
By RYAN HOLMGREN Casper Star-TribuneOctober 15, 2015 - 10:37 am EDT 
LARAMIE, Wyoming — Midway through his junior season, Wyoming wide receiver Jake Maulhardt is already off to a career year. 
After six games, the Camarillo, California, native boasts 30 receptions for 312 yards and three touchdowns. All three stats are career highs. 
"I've been waiting the past two years and just accepting my role," Maulhardt said. "This year, my number's been called a few times and I've gotten opportunities and I've been able to capitalize a little bit on them. It's real exciting." 
Maulhardt, like fellow junior receiver Tanner Gentry, took a backseat to guys like Robert Herron, Dominic Rufran and Jalen Claiborne over the past two seasons. 
Last season, Maulhardt caught 21 passes for 274 yards and one touchdown. And as a freshman in 2013, he hauled in nine catches for 76 yards and a score. 
But now, Maulhardt has proven to be a capable starter, shining atop the depth chart. 
"Jake has shown to be a guy that we can go to," UW coach Craig Bohl said. "While he does not possess great speed, certainly with his physical stature — he's (6-foot-5) — he's a competitive guy who utilizes his body position on some throws." 
That appeared evident last week at Air Force, when Maulhardt had a career-high two touchdown receptions — both in the fourth quarter — among his five catches for 65 yards. 
"It felt good we were able to throw the ball," Maulhardt said. "... It would've felt a lot better with a win, obviously." 
He also turned in a dominant performance in the Cowboys' loss at Washington State in Week 3, when he registered career highs of 10 receptions and 113 receiving yards. 
His big frame is coveted by quarterbacks and despised by defensive backs. 
"He's just a big, physical guy," UW senior quarterback Cameron Coffman said. "As a quarterback, you always like big targets because you can miss a little bit and he's still going to come down with it just with his wingspan, his long arms and things like that. He's really a mismatch for smaller defense backs who cover him." 
Added UW interim wide receivers coach Gordie Haug: "When defenses want to play man-to-man coverage on him, it becomes a big issue for those guys because usually those guys are around 5-10, 5-11 and they're trying to cover a big 6-5 kid at receiver." 
Maulhardt's receiving counterpart, Gentry, ranks 12th nationally with 592 receiving yards and three touchdowns on 33 catches this season. 
Gentry's high production rate helps open opportunities for Maulhardt, and vice versa. 
"I think when a defense looks, they've got to see there's a balanced outfit as far as how they deal with those two guys in particular," UW offensive coordinator Brent Vigen said. "I think that's pretty critical. If you have one guy and you're moving him all over the place, but he's the one guy you're going to, I think it's pretty easy to tilt your defense to that guy. ... You better pay attention to both of them." 
Save for Maulhardt and Gentry, only junior tight end Jacob Hollister (15) owns more than 10 receptions this season. 
The Cowboys hope to find more production from a bevy of freshman receivers getting playing time — Joseph Parker ranks first with four receptions, while James Price has three and Tayton Montgomery has two. 
Just as Maulhardt's impact helps create opportunities for Gentry, Haug believes it will pay dividends for the UW freshmen. 
"So for Jake to continue to grab a bunch of catches and do the things that he's doing will continue to open up plays for those other receivers as well," Haug said. 
Information from: Casper (Wyo.) Star-Tribune, http://www.trib.com
